title: Signs and Symptoms of Ulcerative Colitis
author: Marijke Vroomen Durning, RN

content: Ulcerative colitis affects your colon, which is part of your digestive system. Many conditions can cause stomach pain and digestive issues, so how do you know if you have ulcerative colitis?
It depends on how severe it is and what part of your colon is affected.

sections.heading: Symptoms of Ulcerative Colitis
content: Symptoms of ulcerative colitis can come and go. You might not have any for weeks, months, or even years, and then they can return. There's roughly a 50-50 chance that the effects will be mild.
Still, most people with the disease have a few common issues, including:
Diarrhea

The most common sign of ulcerative colitis is frequent diarrhea with blood or pus in it. You might notice it in the toilet after you go. It’s possible to have blood in your poop and not be able to see it, so you might not realize.

If your disease is severe, the urge to empty your colon can come on fast. You might be able to predict when it will happen. For example, you might have to use the bathroom soon after you eat, or certain kinds of foods, like spicy dishes or food with lots of fiber, might worsen your symptoms. You may even find that stress triggers cramping and an urgent need to use the bathroom. It might be tough to hold diarrhea in and make it to the bathroom in time.

content: Other times, the urge to go is unpredictable. It can even wake you up when you’re asleep. Sometimes, you may feel like you still have to go shortly after a bowel movement, as if you haven't emptied your colon.
Here are some of the most common symptoms of ulcerative colitis.
Pain
Belly pain from ulcerative colitis can feel crampy, and the pain can often feel quite severe. It can happen before a bowel movement or while you're going.
Belly pain from ulcerative colitis can make you feel crampy before a bowel movement. (Photo Credit: E+/Getty Images)
Fatigue
Ulcerative colitis causes several problems that can make you feel very tired:
bullets: Nausea and loss of appetite keep you from eating, which leaves your body low on fuel.
Diarrhea and swelling in your colon make it hard for your body to absorb what it needs for energy.
Bleeding in your colon leaves you with too few red blood cells or anemia.
You don't get enough sleep because you get up often at night to go to the bathroom.

sections.heading: Weight loss
content: Diarrhea, loss of appetite, and the inability to absorb calories from your food can make you lose weight.
Sores
Ulcerative colitis can cause canker sores in your mouth and sores on your skin. You might also get rashes. Read more about skin problems linked to ulcerative colitis.
Frequent urge to pass stools

You will likely have the frequent urge to go to the bathroom, but when you try – there’s nothing there. This is called rectal tenesmus . Up to 30% of people who have ulcerative colitis have tenesmus. It’s caused by the inflammation of your large bowel, which includes your rectum and anus. You may feel pressure in your anus, as if you have to move your bowels, along with pain, cramping, and even involuntary straining.

sections.heading: Severe Symptoms of Ulcerative Colitis
content: Some people with ulcerative colitis can develop severe complications. Contact your doctor right away or seek emergency help, if you notice any of these symptoms:
bullets: Increasing pain, fever, and rapid heartbeat, which could be signs of a toxic megacolon or a perforated colon (hole in the colon). This could lead to an infection and sepsis, which can be fatal.
Blood clots in your veins or arteries. Blood clots can cause deep vein thrombosis, go to your lungs, and cause a pulmonary embolism, or they can go to your brain and cause a stroke.

sections.heading: Signs of Ulcerative Colitis Flare-Up
content: Many people with ulcerative colitis have periods when they have no symptoms, and this can last months or even years for some. This is called remission . Unfortunately, the symptoms often do come back, which is called a flare-up. These are signs you might be having a flare-up:
bullets: Moving your bowels more than five times a day
Loose stools or diarrhea with blood or mucus for more than 3 days

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Ulcerative colitis affects your colon and can cause serious symptoms, including diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and weight loss. Although ulcerative colitis is a colon disease, it can cause other complications outside the gastrointestinal (GI) tract; these include arthritis , mouth ulcers, and skin rashes. If you have symptoms of ulcerative colitis, talk to your doctor as soon as possible. Treatment might put you in remission, a state when you have no symptoms.

sections.heading: FAQs on Symptoms of Ulcerative Colitis
content: Does ulcerative colitis go away?
No, ulcerative colitis doesn’t go away but it can go into remission for up to many years for some people.
What foods trigger colitis?
Food itself doesn’t trigger or cause colitis, but some foods can trigger or worsen symptoms in someone who has ulcerative colitis. These are some of the most common foods that can trigger symptoms:
What are the early warning signs of ulcerative colitis?
If you experience some of these symptoms, they might be early warning signs of ulcerative colitis:
bullets: Foods that have fiber that doesn’t dissolve, such as apple peels and sunflower seeds
Foods with high fiber, such as cabbage and cauliflower
Dairy products, as they contain lactose unless they are marked “lactose-free”
Artificial sweeteners, such as sorbitol, mannitol, and aspartame
High-sugar foods, such as pastries and maple syrup
High-fat foods, such as fried foods
Blood or pus in your poop
Frequent need to go to the bathroom

sections.heading: How serious is ulcerative colitis?
content: Ulcerative colitis is a serious illness. It can cause malnutrition and dehydration. And the longer someone has ulcerative colitis, the higher the risk they have of developing colon cancer.
What are the symptoms of ulcerative colitis in women?

People assigned female at birth have the same symptoms of ulcerative colitis as those assigned male, but they might also have irregular menstrual periods and increased pain during periods, and their diarrhea may get worse then as well. They also have a higher risk of anemia and they can develop a fistula , an opening, between the bowel and the vagina.

Foods with high fiber, such as cabbage and cauliflower
Dairy products, as they contain lactose unless they are marked “lactose-free”
Artificial sweeteners, such as sorbitol, mannitol, and aspartame
High-sugar foods, such as pastries and maple syrup
High-fat foods, such as fried foods
Spicy foods
Alcohol
Caffeine

content_blocks.text: What are the early warning signs of ulcerative colitis?
If you experience some of these symptoms, they might be early warning signs of ulcerative colitis:
associated_bullets: Belly pain
Cramping
Frequent diarrhea
Blood or pus in your poop
Frequent need to go to the bathroom
Weight loss

content: Ulcerative colitis is a serious illness. It can cause malnutrition and dehydration. And the longer someone has ulcerative colitis, the higher the risk they have of developing colon cancer.
What are the symptoms of ulcerative colitis in women?

People assigned female at birth have the same symptoms of ulcerative colitis as those assigned male, but they might also have irregular menstrual periods and increased pain during periods, and their diarrhea may get worse then as well. They also have a higher risk of anemia and they can develop a fistula , an opening, between the bowel and the vagina.
